title: How to record songs on a laptop - Quora

response.answer_text: This depends on what you’re looking to accomplish. I use my set-up for light to moderate projects that include acoustic and electric guitar, vocals, synth, occassional percussion and for some heavier mastering and post-production work. If you’re simply looking to capture scratch tracks, you just need an app for your phone. I recommend Spire, a free multi-track mobile app for musicians on-the-go. It’s way more intuitive than GarageBand and it’s great for capturing the moment. And it just sounds good. I used it to record this while traveling through Indonesia. If you’re looking for something with a little more heft, you’re going to need a DAW (Digital Audio Workstation) and there are several options to consider. You’ll also need a good audio interface for your set-up and a computer with some good ram (8–16gb). Here are some suggestions. You’ll also want a decent mic and stand. Shure makes good, durable and affordable microphones (SM-57, SM58), but nothing beats a quality condenser mic. Moving onto DAWs… I’ve used Ableton Lite, which is the free version. While it doesn’t provide all of the features of the paid version, it’s enough to get you going, and there’s some pretty decent on-board effects for tracking, mixing and mastering. For instance, I recorded this trackages ago with Ableton Lite and I’m pretty happy with the finished product. Though I’ve never used Logic Pro or Pre-Sonus, I’ve worked with some people who have that swear by them. I eventually picked up Pro Tools, but you don’t have to go this route unless you’re handling some big mixing or sound design projects. [1] I do prefer it, but that’s probably because I’ve gotten confortable with the interface and controls. You can check out my most recent project, which I tracked, mixed and mastered through Pro Tools using my Zoom Tac-2 Thunderbolt interface and Macbook Pro. If you do decide to bite the bullet and pick up Pro Tools, there are some really great discounts available for students and educators; make sure to seek these out if you qualify. I’ll leave you with one final note: A lot of people try to argue that Pro Tools is the only way to go, but there are some other options that are more affordable and might suit your needs better. Don’t dismiss your own comfort level and trust your gut. You don’t want to be slogging away for hours in a DAW that you don’t like using. Remember, it’s about finding what’s right for you!

This sounds ridiculously simple, but the best way is to just get started. Make something. (I would also second the previous commenter: Audacity is great and free)  Do your best not to overthink it and just make some music. Far too many people obsess over what kind of "gear" they need and whether or not it will sound "professional" enough. The reality is that a great producer can make anything sound good (or at least better) no matter what gear they have.  When you need to learn how to do something specific Google is your best friend. The resources you'll need are easily found online and the laptop you have now is likely powerful enough to do anything you want if you're a beginner.   Just make stuff. Expect your first tries to be shitty. Expect to get better over time and eventually be embarrassed by your first tries. Keep those first efforts handy for those times when you need to remind yourself that the work really does pay off.   Hope that helps.

It's a great recording and editing package that can record from a USB microphone or an imported audio file and has plenty of really useful editing tools.  Try it out at Audacity®
